choices.text: Vagina, cervix, buccal cavity, and anus

questions.text: The histological slide given below shows the epithelium which occurs in
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The slide shows non-keratinized stratified squamous epithelium
  • It is found in the buccal cavity, lips, the underside of the tongue, upper oesophagus, conjunctiva of eyes, rectum, vagina, etc.
  • The stratified squamous epithelial cells that lack the keratin protein are referred to as nonkeratinized epithelium.

questions.text: The lining layer of fallopian tubes, bronchi, and bronchioles consists of
questions.solution:
The lining layer of fallopian tubes, bronchi, and bronchioles consists of Ciliated columnar epithelium.


  • Ciliated epithelium is a thin tissue that has hair-like structures on it. These hairs, called cilia, move back and forth to help move particles out of our body.
  • Ciliated epithelial tissue is found in the respiratory tract and in the fallopian tubes of women.

Explanation of Other Options:

(Option A) Columnar epithelium is composed of tall, pillar-like cells that are longer than they are wide, with nuclei typically located near the base of each cell. The nuclei are usually oval or elongated in shape.

(Option C) Cuboidal epithelium consists of cube-shaped cells that are approximately equal in height and width, giving them a square or box-like appearance on cross-section. The nucleus is round and centrally located, often prominent in the middle of the cell

(Option D) Squamous epithelium is made up of flat, thin cells with a centrally placed, flattened nucleus, resembling fried eggs in cross-section. These cells are wider than they are tall, and in histological slides, they appear as a thin layer of scales or plates.

questions.text: Which of the following does not have the epithelium shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The slide shown is of transitional epithelium and is not seen in penile urethra
  • Transitional epithelium is found lining the structures of the urinary system, particularly in areas that need to stretch.
  • These structures include the ureters (transport urine from kidneys to bladder), urinary bladder (holds urine), and Prostatic urethra (transports urine from the bladder to outside the body).(Option A, B, and C ruled out)

Penile urethra

  • Lined primarily by pseudostratified columnar epithelium, and near the external urethral orifice, stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Not lined by transitional epithelium.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a compound tubular gland?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Brunner's glands are compound, tubular, mucous glands located in the submucosa of the duodenum. They fill this region so completely that the typical submucosal connective tissue is obscured. Essentially, Brunner's glands represent a continuation of the pyloric glands of the stomach.

Compound Tubular Gland

  • Definition:

A gland with a branched duct system (compound) whose secretory units are tubular.

  • Structure:

Multiple tubular secretory units connected to a branched duct system.

Examples:

  • Brunner's glands (located in the submucosa of the duodenum) secrete alkaline mucus to protect intestinal lining.
  • Seminiferous tubules of the testes, involved in sperm production.
  • Proximal convoluted tubules in kidneys (not a gland but a tubular structure).
  • Function:
    Secretion varies by location but typically involves mucous or serous secretions through tubular secretory units.

choices.text: Different types of cells performing one function
Different types of cells, which are different in structure and function
Similar cells at different regions performing many functions
Similar types of cells held together by connective tissue

questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The compound epithelium consists of more than one layer of cells. It is usually protective in function.
  • They protect against mechanical and chemical stress. Also, it has a limited role in absorption and secretion. These cells cover the skin, buccal cavity, pancreatic ducts, inner lining of salivary ducts, and pharynx.
  • It is arranged as different types of cells performing one function. The function of the compound epithelium is to protect against mechanical and chemical stresses.

questions.text: Which of the following ducts of the glands do not have the same lining epithelium as the excretory duct of the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The excretory duct of the salivary gland (like the striated and excretory ducts) is lined by simple cuboidal to stratified columnar epithelium.
  • The ducts of the sebaceous glands are lined by keratinised stratified squamous epithelium.
  • Also, the gland uses holocrine secretion, not merocrine like salivary/sweat.

Explanation of Other Options:

Sweat Gland (Option A): Duct epithelium is lined by stratified cuboidal

Exocrine Pancreas (Option C)

  • Ducts lined by simple cuboidal to simple columnar epithelium
  • Intercalated → Cuboidal
  • Larger ducts → Columnar

Mammary Gland (Option D): Excretory ducts (lactiferous ducts): Stratified cuboidal to columnar, transitioning to stratified squamous at the nipple

questions.text: Which type of epithelium is characterized by multiple layers of cells with dome-shaped superficial cells that flatten when stretched?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The type of epithelium described is the transitional epithelium, and it is present in the urinary bladder.
  • Transitional epithelium is a specialized epithelium lining most of the urinary tract; hence, it is also called the urothelium.
  • The deepest layer consists of columnar or cuboidal cells, and the middle layer consists of polyhedral or pear-shaped cells.
  • The surface layer consists of large, polypoid, dome-shaped, or umbrella-shaped cells. As the epithelium gets stretched to accommodate urine, the surface cells become flattened.
  • The cells are called transitional due to this apparent change (transition) from stratified cuboidal epithelium in a relaxed state to stratified squamous epithelium when it is stretched

Explanation of Other Options:

Duodenum(Option A):

Epithelium: Simple columnar epithelium with microvilli

Function: Absorption and secretion (contains goblet cells and enterocytes)

Common bile duct (Option C):

Epithelium: Simple columnar epithelium

Designed for transporting bile, not for distension.

Skin (Option D):

Epithelium: Stratified squamous keratinized epithelium

Superficial cells are flattened and dead, forming a protective barrier.

Explanation:

  • The loop of Henle is also called ansa nephroni.
  • It is lined by both the squamous and cuboidal epithelium in different parts.
  • The tubular epithelial cells grow progressively taller throughout the segment until those in the collecting duct form a simple columnar epithelium.

Thick descending limb

  • Lined by: Cuboidal epithelium (similar to proximal tubule)
  • Function: Reabsorbs water and some solutes.

Thin descending and ascending limbs

  • Lined by: Simple squamous epithelium
  • Thin-walled, facilitates passive transport (especially water in descending limb).

Thick ascending limb

  • Lined by: Cuboidal to low columnar epithelium
  • Actively transports Na+, K+, Cl- but is impermeable to water.

Explanation:

  • Microvilli are absent in collecting ducts.
  • They are lined by simple columnar epithelium without microvilli.

The simple cuboidal or columnar epithelium may undergo certain specializations such as:

  • Microvilli - long finger-like projections arising from the surface of the epithelium, which increase the surface area of absorption. If the microvilli are long and are arranged regularly, parallel to one another, they give a striated appearance on light microscopy. However, if the microvilli are arranged irregularly. It gives a brush border appearance. Microvilli are located at:
  • Small intestine - columnar cells with striated microvilli. ( Option A ruled out.)
  • Gall bladder - columnar cells with brush border microvilli. ( Option B ruled out)
  • Proximal convoluted tubule - cuboidal cells with brush border microvilli( Option C ruled out)
  • Stereocilia - long and branching microvilli. Unlike the cilia, the stereocilia are non-motile and hence, the preferred name is stereovilli.

questions.text: Identify the type of cartilage shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above image shows an elastic cartilage.

The elastic cartilage, like the hyaline cartilage, contains individual or small groups of chondrocytes that are surrounded by type II collagen fibrils. However, it differs from hyaline cartilage in that much of the interterritorial matrix consists of fine yellow elastic fibers containing elastin protein.

questions.text: Which of the following stains are used to visualize the elastic fibers present in the elastic cartilage?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The elastic fibers present in the elastic cartilage can be visualised by Verhoeff's stain.
  • The fibers stain dark purple/black with Verhoeff's stain. Verhoeff's stain binds to the elastin protein, which is the main constituent of elastic fibers.
  • Contains hematoxylin, ferric chloride, and iodine
  • Elastic fibers appear black, contrasting with pink or yellow background tissue.
  • Often used in combination with Van Gieson stain (Verhoeff-Van Gieson or VVG) to also highlight collagen.

questions.text: In which of the following types of cartilages is type 1 collagen present?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Type I collagen is present in fibrocartilage.
  • Fibrocartilage (also known as white fibrocartilage) contains both type I and type II collagen. Type 1 collagen is the one present in bones; hence, fibrocartilage is the hardest of the cartilage types

Structure: Dense, fibrous texture; resembles a mix of dense connective tissue and cartilage

Location:

  • Intervertebral discs
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Menisci
  • Insertion of tendons into cartilage

Function: Strong resistance to compression and shear, acts as a shock absorber

Explanation of Other Options:

Hyaline Cartilage (Option A):

  • Collagen type: Type II (not Type I)
  • Appearance: Glassy, homogeneous matrix
  • Location:
    • Nose, trachea, bronchi
    • Costal cartilage
    • Epiphyseal plates
    • Articular cartilage (a subtype of hyaline)
  • Function: Provides smooth surfaces for joint movement and structural support

Elastic Cartilage (Option C):

  • Collagen type: Mainly Type II (plus elastic fibers)
  • Appearance: Similar to hyaline but with dense elastic fibers visible with special stains
  • Location:
    • External ear (auricle)
    • Epiglottis
    • Eustachian tube
  • Function: Provides flexibility and resilience

Articular Cartilage (Option D):

  • Subtype of: Hyaline cartilage
  • Collagen type: Type II
  • Location: Covers joint surfaces
  • Function: Provides a smooth, lubricated surface for low-friction articulation

questions.text: The only excitatory cell in the given slide is present in which marked layers
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The slide show is of the cerebellum, and the only excitatory cell present is the granular cell, which is present in the granular layer

The structures marked in the given image are:

A - Molecular layer: stellate cells, basket cells

B - Purkinje layer: Purkinje cells

C - Granular layer: granular cells, Golgi cells

D - White matter

The cerebellum is covered by pia mater, which is seen as thin connective tissue, with blood vessels lying under it. The cerebellum consists of an outer grey matter (cerebellar cortex) and inner white matter.

questions.text: Identify the type of gland depicted in the following image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows an apocrine gland. There is shedding of the apical portion of the cell during secretion.

  • Mechanism: The apical portion of the cell (containing secretory product) is pinched off and released into the duct.
  • Cell loses part of its cytoplasm, but the nucleus and base remain intact.
  • Examples:
    • Apocrine sweat glands (axilla, areola, groin - scent-producing)
    • Mammary glands (lipid component of milk)
  • Histology: Characterized by "decapitation secretion" - apical blebbing or shedding of cytoplasm.

Explanation of Other Options:

Holocrine Glands(Option A)

  • Mechanism: The entire secretory cell ruptures, releasing its contents into the lumen.
  • Cell fate: The cell dies in the process; it is replaced by basal stem cells.
  • Example:
    • Sebaceous glands (in skin)
    • Meibomian glands (eyelid)
  • Histology: You see cells packed with secretory material, and some disintegrating into the lumen.

Merocrine Glands (also called eccrine)(Option B)

  • Mechanism: Secretions are released via exocytosis, with no loss of cytoplasm.
  • Cell remains intact.
  • Examples:
    • Eccrine sweat glands (thermoregulatory sweat)
    • Pancreatic acini (digestive enzymes)
    • Salivary glands
  • Histology: Clear vesicles forming at the apical surface, but no part of the cell is lost.

Endocrine Glands(Option D)

  • Mechanism: Release hormones directly into blood - no ducts.
  • Secretion is usually by exocytosis, similar to merocrine process, but directed toward capillaries, not ducts.
  • Examples:
    • Thyroid, adrenal, pituitary, pancreatic islets
  • Histology: Highly vascular, with secretory cells in cords or clusters surrounded by capillaries.

questions.text: The space of Disse consists of all of the following except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The space of Disse consists of Microvilli, blood plasma, fat cells except Kupffer cells.

Kupffer's cells

  • These are resident macrophages of the liver.
  • They are located on the luminal side of the sinusoidal endothelium, i.e., inside the sinusoidal lumen, not in the Space of Disse.
  • Function: phagocytose pathogens, old RBCs, and remove gut-derived toxins or debris.

Space of Disse

  • The Space of Disse is the narrow space between hepatocytes and liver sinusoidal endothelial cells.
  • It plays a key role in exchange of substances (nutrients, proteins, metabolites) between blood plasma and hepatocytes.
  • It is also involved in vitamin A storage, immune surveillance, and fibrosis (in disease).

Explanation of Other Options:

Microvilli (Option A):

  • These are extensions of the hepatocyte plasma membrane projecting into the Space of Disse.
  • They increase surface area for absorption and secretion of molecules between hepatocytes and sinusoidal blood.
  • Essential for liver metabolic functions (e.g., albumin uptake/secretion, detoxification).

Blood plasma (Option B):

  • Sinusoidal capillaries in the liver are fenestrated, allowing plasma (but not blood cells) to filter into the Space of Disse.
  • Plasma in this space bathes the hepatocyte microvilli, facilitating nutrient and waste exchange.

Fat cells (a.k.a. Ito cells / Stellate cells) (Option D):

  • Located within the Space of Disse, nestled between hepatocytes and sinusoidal lining.
  • Store vitamin A and lipids in cytoplasmic droplets.
  • In liver injury, these cells can transform into myofibroblast-like cells and contribute to fibrosis by producing collagen.

questions.text: Identify the structure shown in the histological image below.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The above histological image is that of the trachea as identified by the presence of pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium lining, the serous and mucous glands, and hyaline cartilage.

The histological section of the trachea shows the following structures:

  • Respiratory epithelium: Pseudostratified ciliated columnar epithelium with goblet cells
  • Basement membrane
  • Submucosal glands (both serous and mucous parts)
  • Perichondrium
  • Tracheal cartilage
  • Trachealis muscle (smooth muscle).

Explanation of Other Options:

Bronchus(Option B):

  • Epithelium: Still pseudostratified ciliated columnar, but goblet cells become fewer as bronchi branch
  • Cartilage: Not C-shaped rings instead, irregular cartilage plates
  • Glands: Still present but less abundant than trachea
  • Muscle: Smooth muscle layer is more developed and continuous
  • Other features: Lymphoid aggregates (especially in younger individuals)

Bronchiole (Option C):

  • Epithelium: Transitions to simple columnar or cuboidal, no goblet cells in terminal bronchioles
  • Cells: Presence of Clara (Club) cells - involved in detoxification and secretion
  • Cartilage: Absent
  • Glands: Absent
  • Muscle: Prominent smooth muscle layer surrounding lumen

Alveoli (Option D):

  • Structure: Made up of alveolar sacs and ducts
  • Epithelium: Simple squamous epithelium (Type I pneumocytes) + cuboidal Type II pneumocytes
  • Function: Gas exchange - extremely thin barrier
  • Cartilage: Absent
  • Glands: Absent
  • Cilia: Absent
  • Smooth muscle: Sparse; some in alveolar ducts
